keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6 Capitol riot, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the Capitol attack.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier this year as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.
Jeffries criticized Trump’s blanket pardon, emphasizing that threats of violence will not deter democratic participation.
Moynihan’s attorneys noted a history of opioid addiction and political engagement, and the DC judge recommended mental health and drug treatment during incarceration.
A text message from Moynihan stated he would kill Jeffries ‘for the future’ and that he cannot allow Jeffries to live due to political beliefs.
Law enforcement is concerned about rising threats against political figures, especially following recent assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man convicted of participating in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested for threatening to kill U.S. Representative Hakeem Jeffries. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier this year, Moynihan was taken into custody after an anonymous source reported that he stated he would kill Jeffries in New York City 'for the future.' The threat, confirmed through a text message, shows a renewed concern about political violence. Moynihan had a history of opioid addiction and political engagement, and was previously recommended for mental health and substance abuse treatment. His case has ignited debate over the implications of Trump’s blanket pardon of January 6 defendants, especially amid rising threats against political figures like Charlie Kirk, who was recently murdered. This incident reflects growing anxiety about extremism and the safety of elected officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
